sources.data_found: Using a $1 million grant from the National Science Foundation, the university added a cluster of 80 high performance graphics processing units, or GPUs, containing 460,000 processing cores to the VACC, housed in UVM's primary datacenter in South Burlington, over the winter and spring.
This massively parallel cluster is composed of over 70 GPUs capable of over 8 petaflops of mixed-precision calculations based on the NVIDIA Tesla V100 architecture.
In 2019, VACC added DeepGreen, its first GPU computing cluster, comprising 80 GPUs capable of over 8 petaflops of computing power.

It will be capable of over 8 petaflops of mixed precision calculations based on the latest NVIDIA Tesla V100 architecture with a hybrid design allowing high bandwidth message passing across heterogeneous compute nodes.

student_data.notes: Graduate CS data from Petersons shows 23 total graduate students with 11 enrolled in 2024. PhD estimate based on typical program size. Undergraduate CS enrollment estimated based on UVM having 12,276 total undergraduates in Fall 2024 (US News) and CS being a major department in CEMS. The College of Engineering and Mathematical Sciences typically has 15-20% of total undergraduate enrollment, and CS represents approximately 20-25% of CEMS students, suggesting ~600 CS undergraduates. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

gpu_resources.notes:
CALCULATIONS:

1) IceCore system (current as of July 2025):
   - V100 GPUs: 80 across 10 nodes = 8 V100s per node
   - H100 GPUs: 2 nodes × 8 H100s per node = 16 H100 (counted as H100 SXM)
   - A100 GPUs: 2 nodes × 4 A100s per node = 8 A100 (assumed 40GB based on typical configurations)

2) DeepGreen cluster (2019):
   - 80 Tesla V100 GPUs (confirmed in multiple sources)

Note: The 80 V100 GPUs mentioned in the IceCore description likely refer to the existing DeepGreen cluster that IceCore is replacing. Total current GPUs: 16 H100 + 8 A100 + 80 V100 = 104 GPUs. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

analysis_notes: University of Vermont operates the Vermont Advanced Computing Center (VACC) with three clusters: Bluemoon, DeepGreen, and BlackDiamond (now being replaced by IceCore). The DeepGreen cluster from 2019 has 80 V100 GPUs, while the new IceCore system adds 16 H100 and 8 A100 GPUs as of 2025.
